title: Anemometr v.3.1 - With a Speed Sensor

description.text:
1. Rain resistant.
  2. Place for a1120 Hallsensor.
  3. Don't need model support.
  4. The perimeter of the circle is 50 centimetres, thus, at a wind speed of 1 meter per second, the anemometer makes 2 full revolutions.
  5. Need bearing 608ZZ.
  6. Need 2 round neodymium magnet 2x2 mm.
  7. Need a1120 Hallsensor.
  8. The sensor should be bent by 90 degrees, as shown in the preview.
  9. After installation, the sensor must be waterproof, for example using epoxy resin or analogues.

description.text:
This is a print designed to induce PLA curling. PLA curling is a nasty problem that many PLA parts have which causes overhangs, especially semicircular ones, to curl up. This causes lower layers to interfere with higher layers, and if the plastic cools enough it can cause your extruder to knock prints right off your bed. It also gives your parts a rough texture that looks pretty awful. If you're having issues getting the bow of your Benchy to come out nice and clean, this part is a faster and more plastic-friendly way to troubleshoot that problem.

PLA curling is generally fixed by printing colder and adding a lot of active cooling. Get a fan to blow on the tip of your nozzle if you don't have one. If you do have one, make sure it's turned on and blowing full blast. If that doesn't help, print a fan duct to direct air right at the tip of the nozzle. If you still aren't happy, look into getting more fans, switching to centrifugal fans, or even switching plastic suppliers or plastic types (I've heard PETG is pretty nice, but have never tried it).

print_settings.Notes:: I tried this part in several orientations.  It worked best with the flat side on the printer bed.  The determining factor is how well the ears at the bottom of the hole grab the end of the visor.  I didn't like having the flat side completely smooth because it doesn't match the texture of the other materials in the vehicle, but the print was the best in this orientation.

description.text:
This is the mount that holds up the sun visor in a 2008 Subaru Forester. On my 10 year old car, the visor mount cracked and the visor fell out, so I designed this replacement. It works great. I would imagine that it works in other model years and maybe even other Subaru models as well, but I do not know for sure. I printed this in ABS and it works great. Keeps the sun out of your eyes!

SolidPart is from SolidWorks 2016.

title: Squizzle! A Supports Free Squirrel Sculpt
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Squizzle is a squirrel holding an acorn. He is a quick sculpt I made from a more complex squirrel rig I am working on (planning a squirrely doll).

It is part of an experiment to see how many models I can get out of one rig.

Squizzle prints with no supports! Hooray!

His height is 130mm but is detailed enough to scale up (although if you scale much bigger and you may need to use some support for the base of the acorn) and should be sturdy enough to scale down well too.

These Squizzles were printed using the very lovely Polyalchemy PLA in:

Elixir Crimson Red
Elixir Purple Rain
Elixir Gold

https://www.polyalchemy.com/

Squizzle was sculpted in Blender.

Notes:

The Squizzles shown here are printed with .02 layer height, 15% infill with 2 perimeters.

They took about 3 hours each.

description.text:
I tried out a connector piece from another design and didn't like the result so I went ahead and designed my own. I'm using it to connect the vertical extrusions to the horizontal extrusions for an AM8 conversion.

The size is adequate and there seems to be just enough room for movement in the hole to get it into the correct orientation. There are no ridges to guide it along the slots so this part relies more on friction and a tight fit than machined parts. Designed to be printed as uploaded, not as pictured.

0.32mm layer height, 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

50% to ensure a pretty strong part

Notes:

2 outlines, 3 top and bottom layers (increase bottom layers to 4 if you tend to like to squish the filament well down onto the plate!)

I printed on 2mm PEI sheet using ABS in an enclosure.

There should be no post process work required. If you are using m5 parts you could consider widening the holes out a little using a drill to get a better fit. If you're printing with high infill the part should remain relatively sound.

Designed using three cubes, three cylinders and some difference operations within OpenSCAD. If printing these using a smaller nozzle you could round the corners of the design for a more comfortable finished part. At 0.4mm you don't tend to get too many sharp edges!

I'm a big fan of the Rick and Morty show and this is for all the people that want to be Rick for Halloween.

I'm pretty sure that this doesn't break any rules if it does just tell me and ill do my best to fix it.
if you need help printing just ask. :)

I'm also going to include one without a "light bulb" so you can add your own or be hooking up an LED under the casing

I was asked by a friend to create a ring that would guide his drywall crew to precisely position his home theater speakers. Since the speakers are exceptionally large (10") he was unable to locate a suitable mounting ring at a reasonable cost. The ring as posted will provide a 10.769" guide hole for a 10.75" speaker frame. The metal brackets were ordered online. Overall cost was about $10 a frame, probably less but I had a few repeats due to edge warping.

There are two versions of the large frame, sometimes the edge would lift during the long print so I added an 'overprint' area to keep things flat. For those of you lucky few who do not have the occasional lifted corner or edge I've included a stripped version of just the frame. I recommend printing the mounts vertically to avoid the need for support material that is difficult to remove in tight spaces.

Two half frames make a whole, use 3/8" long #8 screws to attach the mounting spacers to the assembled frames. When installing in the rafters adjust the position of the metal stringers where the bottom of the ring will be at the finished height of the exposed drywall.

The frame is just a guide for the drywall installation, it does not provide sufficient strength to support a speaker on it's own. Once the drywall if fitted to the guide and the gap between the guide and drywall is filled the drywall will take the weight of the speaker.

Remixed as original wasn't long enough to latch in trapdoor, needed to make hole for PPC fan as it was stopping the trapdoor from sitting flush, also the latch wasn't high enough and has been replaced with the latch from the trapdoor by dvoelkel.

I recommend that you also print https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2229188 if using this model..

2017-09-11 Improved strength of latch, adjusted post height to better support accelerator card.

I came across Jon Vogel's Dropper Paint Bottle Holder design and thought it looked useful, but it was a bit too big to comfortably fit on the print bed of my Makergear M2.

I went ahead and re-designed it briefly to be 4-wide instead of 5-wide, and further broke it down to be printable in separate panels that could be fit together on the edges like a puzzle. Figured it would make assembly and alignment easier, and gluing it together would be that much more straightforward.

The shelves are at a 45 degree angle. I should have probably exported them flat side down, sorry.

The Penrose stairs, also known as the impossible staircase, is a two-dimensional depiction of a staircase in which the stairs make four 90-degree turns as they ascend or descend yet form a continuous loop. Although the staircase is conceptually impossible, it does interfere with your perception since it looks like a person could climb forever and never get any higher.

Watching the video is the easiest way to see how it works.
https://youtu.be/VAAZBhA8Pfc

title: Pergo HP LaserJet 2100M Single Sheet Feed Door Latch

description.text:
I had a HP Laser Jet 2100M with a broken single sheet feed door broken.
You could not close the door and have it stay. there is a tiny little plastic piece that would hold the door shut. With it broken the door just comes open again.

In that area is a cavity that this piece I designed slides into with a pressure fit and takes the place of the retainer clip.
I'm thinking that this might be a common problem, so I posted my fix for it. I've received a lot of "Collects" and adds to "to be printed" so I guess many others have had this issue too!

I printed in ABS because ABS has more give but it's not "flexible", but I see no reason that PLA or nylon would not be a perfect match too.

OpenDungeonTiles: Wall Corner Short Roughstone 2x2

V1: The lock is now a nub lock in the full kit

Please note that there are two sizes of walls the corner wall is smaller. If you need just regular interior roughstone wall look here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2465478

Assembly:
Walls take 5mm magnetic spheres
Floors take 3mm magnetic spheres
Bases take 5mm magnetic spheres
Insert 5mm magnetic spheres into the 2 holes, glue thinner piece on top. When placing other parts onto the base, the thinner glued on part should be on the bottom. (I am working on assembly video/instructions)

Open Forge Compatible.
Open Lock Compatible (Note: You must use the lock in my files it is thinner)

Glossary:
FullKit
Files marked FULLKIT at the beginning are all the pieces you need to assembly for a full base tiles/corner tile/wall tiles etc... They usually include the base, basecap, floor, floorcap, and walls with wallcap if applicable.
Kit
Files marked KIT at the beginning are the pieces you need to assembly a full tile without the base pieces (because there is a base kit, this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463765)
KITDUAL
The is the same as a kit, but a files that contains two copies of the part. Cut down on copy paste in slicers.
Something else
These are the individual pieces if you wish to print a single part of the tile. Not all the files are done for these, and you may have to pull them out of the kits. (working on this)

Questions - use the comments, send me a message here or on patreon.

I have a great job. One of the guys ask if I know where he could get a plate to mount a plastic mannequin head to a tripod. About 40 minutes later I hand him a finished plate and watch his jaw drop. Isn't 3D printing fun?

This is a flat plate that can be used to mount a light object on a tripod. It's designed to use a 2" x 1/16" fender washer with a 1/4" hole through the center. The nut is a US Standard 1/4 - 20, the fit though the hole of the plate is designed to be snug. The fender washer was added to improve the amount of lateral force the plate can withstand. The nut and washer are glued to the plate with E6000 adhesive. I used 4 flat head screws to attach the plate.

title: 3 in 1 150W Discharger Voltage Tester Balancer For Lipo Battery

description.text:
Housing for the 150W lipo discharger that many RC guys are using. Has a press fit compartment for the actual controller and holders for the three light bulbs fixtures. The light bulb controller and all wires are located underneath the controller. There is also a storage compartment with a slide out cover to hold the battery cable and the three light bulbs when not in use. The unit ships with a Deans style T connector and I purchase a 9" long XT-60 adapter cable and it is about the perfect length to be able to store and still easily reach the battery balance connector location when in use.

Hardware Required
Qty 18 x 4-40 Socket Head Cap Screws 0.500 long. (6 for bulbs holders & 12 for cover)
Qty 6 x 4-40 hex nuts (for light bulb holders)

The 12 screws for the cover can be shorter (I wouldn't go less than 0.250 long) but the design will accommodate up to 0.500 long.

The threads for the bottom cover are designed into the part, but the screws will end up cutting the plastic a bit on first installation. I find it best to go slow with the screws about 1 turn at a time and then allow the screw to cool before continuing. When turned continuously the screws will get hot enough to melt PLA and ABS and destroy the threads.

I printed in PLA and have successfully discharged a 1500mah 4S battery from 16.8v to 14.8v without any overheating of the plastic parts (all 3 bulbs were on). However the bulbs get VERY HOT, DO NOT LEAVE UNATTENDED. I have not tested higher voltages than 4S.

Design files are included for easy modifications, Print Files are high resolution and do not always render on the thingiverse server.

Glossary:
FullKit
Files marked FULLKIT at the beginning are all the pieces you need to assembly for a full base tiles/corner tile/wall tiles etc... They usually include the base, basecap, floor, floorcap, and walls with wallcap if applicable.
Kit
Files marked KIT at the beginning are the pieces you need to assembly a full tile without the base pieces (because there is a base kit, this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463765)
KITDUAL
The is the same as a kit, but a files that contains two copies of the part. Cut down on copy paste in slicers.
Something else
These are the individual pieces if you wish to print a single part of the tile. Not all the files are done for these, and you may have to pull them out of the kits. (working on this)

title: Taz 4 (or 5) Hot End Extruder Bracket Clamp (Updated 09/21/17)

description.text:
Updated with v2 parts 09/21/2017: Added longer V2 parts that use two screws for better clamp support, similar to a woodworkers clamp. I you are shooting for light and cheap stick with the V1 clamps. They work. Not quite as well with a Hex Hot End extruder bracket (V2). Works better with a V1 Buddahschnozzel. V2 works well on both. A bit more hardware and the weight is really not much. Also found some M3 x 14mm long replacement screws for the bearing mount. Works better that the 12mm long screws. Got the 14mm long M3s at Amazon for another project. Probably available at Home Depot and Lowes also. Make sure not to lose your thin M3 washers from the bearing holder which get used with the new clamps. The V1 parts are still here also. They are the two clamp files with no version number. the V2 parts have a 2 in the title.

Orig:
I still use my Taz 4 which I bought in 2014. One thing that always annoyed me was the fact that the hot end assy holder which only has one screw at the top (for quick assembly) allows the weight of the extruder and hotend parts to allow the bracket to pull forward at the top corners of the bracket. I usually use some plastic clamps to pul the bracket back at the corners to the X-carriage and double bearing holder. I would be happier if the design used screws at the corners. The result of the corners pulling away from the carriage is some slop in the hotend which causes deviations and irregularities in the paths as the hot end changes direction. Some of that can be seen as patterns over a large flat surface. The clamps help some, but the entire system has play so you cannot get rid of all of it. Also, poor adjustment and leveling of the bed can make this issue worse.
Anyway, I have used some cheap plastic clamps from Harbor Freight but they pop off easily because of the geometry, and I decide to do something to improve the clamping.
The result is what you see here. It uses two different clamp pieces and a 6-32 x 1.25" long machine screw and two #6 nuts (because that's what I had). You could use M3 hardware of the same length. On each corner the existing outer top double bearing holder screw and washer is used to hold the shorter part of the clamp. It is a bit too short for my taste so I will get an M5-.5x15mm screw when I get a chance. The stock one is a bit short even though I recessed it into the clamp. But it works for now. Note that the long clamp has two bumps on one side that go against the extruder bracket. On the left side those two bumps actually straddle the gusset. The extra nut is to help keep the bracket straighter. As you can see it starts to tilt as it is tightened. You only need to tighten it enough to pull the bracket against the X-carriage; just lightly tightened. If I figure out something better, I will revise this. This design will fit both the V1 Budahschnozzle and V2 all metal extruder brackets. (The heights are different). You may need to clean up the holes with a .140" and .130", or close, bit to insert the screws more easily. I used a fairly high fill: 90%. I used ABS with a .5 nozzle, .20mm layers and slowed it down about 20% to get the parts to stick well.
There are other solutions involving a major overhaul to the X carriage parts, but this is a fairly easy improvement.

It's much cheaper to purchase pane glass rather than plexiglass, and the cutting is free (Lowes). The bolt printed here is much easier on the glass bore hole than a steel bolt would be. Before anyone asks, all you need is a carbide drill bit designed for drilling into materials such as tile & glass. I picked up a set of four at Lowes for less than $10.

title: OLED display case with room for jogwheel and Micro SDRAMPS

description.text:
Update: Knob added. It should fit on an ALPS encoder with a 6mm shaft.  
My 20x4 LCD display broke, so I ordered a new one. This time I decided to order an OLED display, because it looks cool.   
I was fed up with the way I had a separate jogwheel, SDRAMPS and display. I decided to cram it all into a single, new box. The OLED display is a little thinner than the LCD, and I felt it needed a little protection. A piece of Plexiglas cut to 84mmx32mm can be mounted in front of the display module.  
The design is untested, but it should all work. My Mendel is still printing it at the moment, so I can't tell if it will all fit well.

title: Pixhawk (or other FC) mount for MFD Nimbus

description.text:
The Nimbus comes with a pre-installed pdb which looks nice but is rather crappy in terms of filtering and that gives not enough room for a pixhawk.

I decided to remove the stock pdb and use a Matek 6s PDB (5/10V) plus a 5A 5V UBEC for redundance and clean powering the peripherals.

Using a large battery (12Ah6s) there is not that much room inside the Nimbus`rear.

Use these parts to get it all ;)

1.) First mount the rear_PDB_mount using the original screws.
2.) mount your pdb using lowest standoffs
3.) Mount the pixhawk_mount. It comes in three versions, depending how high your pdb is and how many cables you have coming out your pixhawk. The 0mm version gets closest to the top so closing the lid could become an issue. The 10mm version gives you not much room on your pdb so you might want to go with angled connectors here.

OpenDungeonTiles: Diagonal Exterior Roughstone 2x2

Assembly:
Walls take 5mm magnetic spheres
Floors take 3mm magnetic spheres
Bases take 5mm magnetic spheres
Insert 5mm magnetic spheres into the 2 holes, glue thinner piece on top. When placing other parts onto the base, the thinner glued on part should be on the bottom. (I am working on assembly video/instructions)

Open Forge Compatible.
Open Lock Compatible (Note: You must use the lock in my files it is thinner)

Glossary:
FullKit
Files marked FULLKIT at the beginning are all the pieces you need to assembly for a full base tiles/corner tile/wall tiles etc... They usually include the base, basecap, floor, floorcap, and walls with wallcap if applicable.
Kit
Files marked KIT at the beginning are the pieces you need to assembly a full tile without the base pieces (because there is a base kit, this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463765)
KITDUAL
The is the same as a kit, but a files that contains two copies of the part. Cut down on copy paste in slicers.
Something else
These are the individual pieces if you wish to print a single part of the tile. Not all the files are done for these, and you may have to pull them out of the kits. (working on this)

author: manabun

title: Mini Calibration pieces! For checking how level your build plate is

description.text: Hey guys! I'm in charge of my school's 3D printer and recently we've been having a lot of problems with leveling the build plate. Turns out that our rubber pads have worn down and the build plate has been coming out of alignment. Currently, we are using a fix seen here (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43050) until we can get a more permanent fix, but until then, we are having to level the build plate quite a bit. However, sometimes I level it and I think I have it right, but then I print something, and it doesn't come out correctly. For big prints, that can be a lot of wasted filament. So I designed these neat little calibration pieces so that I could quickly test calibration before I started a big print. Each calibration pieces features curves (in the form of a circle, heart, and letter C) as well as straight lines and sharp edges (the square and the heart) to make sure your printer is level exactly the way you want it! A single calibration piece prints in about 3-4 minutes and weighs less than a gram! For those of you who really want to make sure the build plate is leveled well, I have a second file with five calibration pieces, one in each corner and one in the middle. It takes about 15 minutes to print and 2 grams, but those 15 minutes could well be worth it on something that takes a couple of hours to print. Best of luck!

0.2 mm layer height,
2% infill (it can print with zero) slice it up and print it! it can be a bit difficult to get off the build plate, but I find that needle nose pliers or a razor make short work of it.

description.text:
I designed this for my bike, the handlebar is 30mm in diameter. Basically I saw the existing modular mounting system and decided if i could use the existing system with a support for a bicycle handlebar it would be a perfect expansion. A little research led to this. READ THE INSTRUCTIONS BEFORE PRINTING OR YOU WILL REGRET IT!!!!
Update:
The new version has four versions, two designed for flexible filament as before and two redesigned for use with PLA. Also all the versions now use 5mm bolts instead of 3mm for tightening and there are versions of both materials with the hinge rotated 90 degrees. Have fun with them!

USE A FLEXIBLE FILAMENT!!!! Seriously, Ninjaflex might do, I'd use PETG cause its springy but not too flexible so it holds its shape and if the bolt comes loose it doesn't fall off. Oh, and put it on it's side, I'm lazy so I didn't do that already, the supports are important for this or it won't fit with the rest of the system.
Update: If you use the PLA version than don't use flexible filament, use PLA because its cheaper, if less reliable.

Remove supports and brim. Gently pull the jaws apart enough to slip onto bike handlebars. Tighten to Handlebars using an M5 Bolt and nut. Attach your mounting system using an M5 bolt and nut. DO NOT USE THE MODELLED BOLTS INCLUDED IN THE MOUNTING SYSTEM! I tried that and I overtightened the bolt on the phone clamp a bit, it broke the bolt and I almost dropped my phone as the clamp went slack.

Long slender screwdriver with standard handle. I needed a set of small screwdrivers for my bicyle repair toolkit. I wanted maximium versitility in the smallest space. Stores sell combo bits and bit drivers, but most have huge handles and won't fit in my toolkit. 3D printer to the rescue! I designed a medium sized slender handle and printed it up. It works great. The design borrows heavily from this blender tutorial, with some changes and enhancements: http://pages.uoregon.edu/art3d/driver/driver25.html

1) Print handle (I used ABS)
2) Purchase bits
3) Drive screws I recommend that you print the first 1/2" (1 cm) or so and verify that the bits fit correctly. You can use the scale feature of your host software or slicer to adjust the hole size, since no other dimension really matters. You can either purchase the extra long bits like I did or get a magnetic bit holder extension and glue that into the handle. The bit holder will probably work better if you plan on changing the bits often.

comments.text: It doesn't seem to be properly scaled on Cura. Unless , of course, your bits are 0.8mm long.

Attaching to head

I attached these to my head through cutting off a piece of 1.75mm filament the size of the circumference of my head.

I then used a heat gun to melt the horns to the filament and the filament ends to each other on the back.

description.text:
I like quadruped robot design by Jason Workshop (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2311678)
also by Manic-3D-print
(https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2317065)

but i need that can changeable like Size, more Servo's, more Leg's, also using arduino nano, bluetooth, and battery lipo 2S.

so i decide to remix, and rebuild it.

all files is inside rar

include modified code from https://github.com/manic-3dprint/ez-arduino-minikame

all you need:

  1. bolt M3 10mm ( 6pcs, 10 pcs, etc, depend on your leg size )
  2. bolt M2 8mm for the body ( 8 pcs )
  3. Servo 9g (8 pcs, 12 pcs, 16 pcs, etc, depend on your leg size )

infill:

  1. Leg parts 100%
  2. body bottom 75%
  3. body middle 50%
  4. body top 50%
  5. head 30%

you can also make arm robot using Leg parts :)

Note Update:

  1. some part already include support.
  2. I make 2 different body, using 2 pcs Battery 18650, and 1 pcs Battery Li-po 2S 1300mah

comments.text: Could you tell me what electronics I need besides the arduino nano, servos, an esp8266, and the ultrasonic sensor to build this? I saw you linked to some other projects but they seem to be using different components like a custom board or bluetooth module....I may just be missing something but I do not have much experience with arduinos and I was going to try to build this project to learn on. Love it by the way.
comments.author: Schmekles

comments.text: Thank you so much for the info, I was wondering about the current draw with so many servos. This has been a great learning project for me. As far as the ESP8266 goes, it looks like I have another learning curve to plow through as I know absolutely nothing about that module other than it relates to WIFI. Can I ask how the esp8266 allows for the more advanced motions?
comments.author: mikerobin

comments.text: minimal current is 2A, so you need external DC buck converter, for adding another advance motions, you need to modified minikame code, and also esp8266 code, see html code inside esp8266 firmware,
comments.author: mikerobin

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback! I now have the bot walking but it will not go into the other modes like dance, or moonwalk ect... it just walks for a while, stops and jumps up and down a bit then keeps walking.  Any suggestions?? I am using the code from your RAR file.
comments.author: mikerobin

comments.text: btw, you need esp8266 to control happy, moonwalk etc
comments.author: mikerobin

comments.text: dont use voltage from arduino for srvo, use different source, or use different voltage regulator, arduino cant support more than 3 servo 9g in same time
comments.author: mikerobin

comments.text: Can I ask what shield/board did you use to control? In the video it looks like you are using the Arduino Nano but im not sure. The inside compartment is too narrow for my Nano boards.
comments.author: mikerobin

comments.text: yes, im using arduino nano with custom pcb
comments.author: mikerobin

comments.text: you need modified the code to add another servo

author: San_Crispino

description.text: This is a filament holder I made for my Metamaquina 2. It snaps right on the top of my printer without any screws or assembly/disassembly.

Just print the two supports and they should be ready to go. I used a 12 mm aluminum tube for the holding the spool, but I also included an STL for printing your own pin, in case you don't have a suitable tube. The files are exactly the same, but you can print one at a time using the "Single" version or both at the same time using the "Double".
I've had some issues with warping, so I would recommend printing one at a time, but if you have solved all your warping issues, just print them both at the same time.

print_settings.Resolution:: Printed at .2mm but it doesn't matter
print_settings.Notes:: *** If your printer is well tuned then this should fit well, but many print a little "fat" (see my last picture with dimensions/dimensions as printed).  If that's the case with yours try printing it at 102% so it does not fit too tight.

title: Anet A8 X-Axis Retainer Clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This retainer clips over the right-hand X-axis carriage and registers inside it and against the X-axis guide rods preventing them from pushing out. This will allow you to tighten the X-axis belt as tight as you want without misaligning/bending the Z-axis guide rods or screws.

This also prevents you from needing to buy a longer X-axis belt as most tensioners that push against the X-axis rods require.

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

Printed at .2mm but it doesn't matter

Infill:

20%

Notes:

It can be printed with either side up/down.

I printed it with the arced cutout on the bottom with supports in there, with good cooling supports are probably not necessary in this orientation.

It could also be printed with the arc/registration block on the top with supports under the block. The advantage to this orientation is that if you are really worried about the finish your supports leave anyplace where they will touch will be inside the X-axis carriage.

*** If your printer is well tuned then this should fit well, but many print a little "fat" (see my last picture with dimensions/dimensions as printed). If that's the case with yours try printing it at 102% so it does not fit too tight.

Please like, share and post "I made it" if you do.

Suggestions for modifications, new designs, and tips/donations are always welcome!

comments.text: My A8 has the rods about 2-3 mm inside the carriage. Unfortunately this makes your retainer 100% useless.
comments.author: FxDx

comments.text: Have you measured if Z rods are straight like that?  Mine are dead straight with the X rods flush with the end of the carriage.  I haven't seen any that are properly lined up with the rods ending inside the carriage, and one that lines up with them slightly outside (though I suspect that they were not fully seated on the other side).  Mine bound up and the Z-axis motors would start skipping steps with the rods anything but flush.
comments.author: FxDx

comments.text: My X rods move easy in the right side carriage, so there is no way to bend my Z-rods. It goes all the way up and down with no problems.
comments.author: GrolarBear

comments.text: This looks bloody brilliant!

comments.text: I'm still trying to put everything together. I didn't print anything with it so far but I've done extruder calibration and I was quite happy with the performance. Most of the issues with E3D hotends are caused by the heatbrake. Just be sure your ptfe tubing is pushed all the way down so there is no gap between ptfe and the heatbrake and that the heatbrake internal diameter is 2mm.. I got some chinese E3D clones and the heatbrake internal diameter was about 1.8mm :/, causing almost constant jams..
comments.author: sudonano

comments.text: I'm printing very reliably with my (original) E3D v6 hotend. I was wondering about reliability due to the comments below about " the 30mm fans arent pushing enough air for the nozzle cooler", but I realize now this might be with regards to the layer cooling?
comments.author: Crashoverride

comments.text: Not much really as there is no space to make them bigger. I have move them a bit further from the heating block and narrowed air outlets
comments.author: Crashoverride

comments.text: WHats the actual diff with the latest ducts?
comments.author: Janjoh

comments.text:
Good observation :D.. maybe I should call it 'Fallout edition' hahaha
That's probably because filament cooling fans are mounted to close to the side of the hotend cooling channel but there is just no space to fix this issue. I've tried to improve fan ducts and the air channel between the fans and the fan ducts but that's all. I have re-done fan ducts to add more clearance for the heating block and the ducts.. narrowed and corrected the angle of the air output, will see if this will help a bit. I was actually planning to use 'remote blower fan' and use flexible duct like this one (25mm) http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/Cold-Air-Feed-For-Induction-Kits-Braking-Flexible-Intake-Ducting-Pipe-Black-Red-/222600574110?var=&hash=item33d407349e:m:mLNA2-hR3dY9vNpm88LG3kw
And the second option are two radial fans..
comments.author: Crashoverride

comments.text: Another personal observation; the 30mm fans arent pushing enough air for the nozzle cooler.  I knew it would be an area of concern, but having received the fans, it is actually a bit worse then i thought....
comments.author: Janjoh

comments.text: If you have the "new" E3Dv6 hotend (With the silicone cover) it actually touches the nozzle cooler ducts. That might be a problem. What material do you use for yours?
comments.author: Janjoh

comments.text: I've printed them in ABS. I was actually planning to buy those silicone covers, shame I don't have one to check. Do you know how thick approx. are the walls? I can't find any info..  Thanks

comments.text: Mine (e3d originals) come to 1,75mm when measured with a cheap-ass-chinese-digital-caliper-from-ebay.

comments.text: Thanks Jan, I will see what I can do to add some more clearance between heating block and the fan ducts.

remixed_from.author: josefcub
remixed_from.title: MendelMax Vertical X Axis Ends & Carriage

title: MendelMax Vertical X Axis Ends & Carriage - 10mm Z

description.text:
After successfully getting as much Z height from my first MendelMax as I could with these carriages:

MendelMax Vertical X Axis Carriages

I promptly dismantled it and sold its frame to fund a self-built Prusa i3 clone. Long story short, a few months later, I once again have a MendelMax! Thanks to the Postal Service, a large amount of the plastics in the kinematics were completely shattered. Since I had to replace the gantries anyway, I thought I'd install my previous vertical carriages onto this printer.

This machine, however, had 10mm smooth rods on the Z axis. Rather than reprint the Z tops and motor mounts, and replace them with 8mm rods, I decided to modify my previous carriage design to hold the LM10UU bearings that the machine came with.

Surprisingly, it's coming together and seems to work perfectly. So now, I share the design with you!

Technical Details

The Z axis smooth rods are 10mm in diameter, but the lead screw mounts are designed for 8mm TR-8x2 brass nuts, with four-screw flanges for attachment. LM10UU or LM10LUU bearings should work well here, as well as TR8 eBay leadscrews with the flanged nuts.

The rod distances (30mm smooth/leadscrew for Z, and 50mm smooth/smooth for X) are the same as in the "standard" Mendel design and do not require customized motor mounts or upper vertex rod stays.

Speaking of the smooth rods, X is still 8mm, while Z is now 10mm.

You likely will need a longer belt for the X axis. The original, stock, belt was too short for this configuration by an inch or two.

The X carriage itself has holes designed to securely hold a metal NEMA 17 motor mount. These work well for mounting Titan extruders.

There is no provision for mounting an X axis end stop switch. I'm re-using the existing one for this experiment.

The LM10UU bearings I use literally just snapped into the half-pipe provided. However, to get them seated correctly, you will likely need to file down or otherwise fit the overhang so that one of the bearings slides snugly into the circular hole next to the lead screw mounting holes.

Use your favorite flavor of zip tie to ensure that the bearings don't go anywhere.

This mod gave me, with a clone Titan extruder, and clone V6 hotend, 145mm of vertical height. I can push that to around 155mm, if I don't home the axis before lowering it, and I choose to lose ~30mm of X.

Bonus

For Z, I have included an end stop screw mount that attaches to the X carriage's 8mm rods. It's designed to hit this Z end stop mount:

XYZ End Stops for Mendelmax 1.5+

Come to think of it, this will work with my 8mm rod version of these carriages, too!

Attribution

I used:

  • the "roundedRect" OpenSCAD module by WilliamAAdams
  • the excellent zip-tie LM8UU bearing holder by skarab

I've added them as remixes on the side, and attributed them in the included source code for the parts. You will need skarab's STL file in order to fully render my SCAD source, and you will need to change the file path in the source to point at your version.

Caveat Emptor

Until I'm finished rebuilding this particular MendelMax, I am marking this as a Work in Progress, and consider it experimental. I don't believe I'll need to edit these carriages again, but I'd rather be safe than sorry.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

45% or MORE

Notes:

Printed in IC3D natural ABS filament.

File down the overhangs such that the LM10UU bearing fits snugly in the circular hole provided.

You will also likely need to ream out the 8mm X axis rod holes, in order for them to fit snugly.

Remember, the higher the infill value, the stronger the part. These parts bear weight and considerable stress.

description.text:

  8. The sensor should be bent by 90 degrees, as shown in the preview.

title: GoWORX freeride style universal smartphone holder gopro camera mount

description.text:
GoWORX style universal smartphone mount.

I designed this mount from scratch using the GoWORX freeride style mount as inspiration. I didnt trust my smartphone to existing designs on thingiverse that use elastics and springs for the compression hold and didnt really want to incorporate hardware like threaded rods and nuts so I came up with this variant.I wanted a fully printed smartphone mount that was strong and reliable and ready to go off the printer. This mount allows you to use your smartphone with all your existing gopro accessories.

*Printing orientation, wall thickness and infill is critical to strength so read the notes if its not obvious to you.

I added a small compression spring I harvested off an old RC car strut to sit around the screw in the mount so it will open automatically as you loosen the screw. This is not necessary but does make it function a bit nicer.

title: MPCNC - Belt Tensioner Parametric Remix for US or IE Version added pin

description.text:
In case your belts/parts are like mine, and although though the single-belt side opening is smaller than two belts it still slips (because the part spreads under tension), I added a "pin" for the belt to wrap around so it is 100% locked.

Of course, you can achieve the same effect by putting a bolt or anything really through the loop that is formed, but if you want to do it with no additional parts, just print some of these.

It's a bit more annoying to mount the belt, and quite a bit more difficult to remove it, but still just fine.

I shaved a little off the top profile to give some extra bolt head clearance since I had some issues with an oversized head not sitting flat

title: Duet Wifi box with delta mount

description.text:
First, I'm French, so my english is not perfect, sorry about that, it's genetic since Napoleon.

=================
You printed it ? did you like it ? TIP me few bucks or local pesos, It'll cover my daily coffee/beer/baguette consumption cost ;-)
=================

Changelog :

  • 2017/07/09 : V1-1 : fixed holes in the box in order to use M3 screws for triangle mounting and M3 (with nut) up to M4 (for M3 cylinder nut insert) for the Duet mount
  • 2017/07/08 : V1 : Initial release

Story : I really liked the Tevo Little Monster Duet3D Cover, but it didn't feed all my need,

What it is :

  • A box for Duet Wifi control board
  • 4 Cable pass-through inserts (in flex)
  • 2 mounts to attach the box into the inner triangle of a Delta Printer (In my case the upper triangle

Notes :

  • For an unknown reason my STL are not generated in the position where it should be printed, pick up the larger face, only the Box could require supports, not the rest of the parts
  • Cable_pass-through_V1.stl are printed in FLEX (10% ~ 20 % infill) it's not mean to be printed with standard plastic.
  • top cover has holes for a 120mm fan
  • box contains 8 holes, 4 with integrated spacers for the Duet and 4 to attach mounting parts
  • 1.75 filament can be used as pin joint for the top cover
  • I printed mine in PETG (Dailyfil) and FLEX for cable pass-through ( Polyflex)
  • Mount parts are design to be fixed on a 2020 extrusion (so it can be fixed to 2040, 2060) the body is not in full contact with the box in case you want to drill holes in the bottom of the box and need space for the screw heads.

Tweaks from the original model (because it's a remix) :

  • I removed few filets for a better first layer and reduced the thickness of the bottom
  • changed the attachment of the top case to reduce "wobbling" and allow a 1.75mm filament as the pin joint.
  • add a simple lock-up mechanism.
  • moved and changed the holes on the sides of the box to allow my cable pass-through part printed in flex to be inserted and stay in place :)
  • added cable pass-through part (printed in flex) so it can be easily removed, or updated to more specific needs
  • added mount for fixing the box in the inner triangle of a delta printer.

Printer:

Custom delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Additional options :

  • 3 walls
  • single extrusion for perimeter and infill (Simplify3D)

Support is kind of mandatory for the windows, especially if you've got bad bridging with your printer. The flex inlet

Cable pass-through are printed in FLEX, it won't work with classic plastic. if you don't have flex, just keep the holes are they are :)

A simple .25 in beam that's 8 inches long. Test the accuracy of your bed leveling, either auto or manual. Also you can print several and test the repeatability and accuracy of your hardware. Even speed testing is an option to find out how fast you can make one, or several? Good luck!

My first attemp of a 3D printable windmill. It generates power using an old cd-drive closer motor and uses it on a 3V LED. There is alot to improve. If you have suggestions, i would love to read them in the comments. This is work in progress. There will be some changes in near future.

For now it has a transition around 1:30. This seems to be too much. Alot of friction going on, so you need alot of airflow to start spinning it. The motor is spinning faster then it would need, as it starts going.

I have modded a 16" prop from my old octo with some depron, to extend its wings.Will replace this soon.

I plan to test different transitions and add them to this thingi afterwards.

Components used:

  • 16" APC propeller - will create a printable blade
  • A piece of shrink tube to fix the propeller onto the shaft
  • Old CD drive closer motor, to generate some power - no power measures yet
  • Rubberband as belt for driving the motor
  • 3.3 Volt RGB LED

About 4 months ago my boss came to me for a cheap solution for our docking points on our forklift terminals. The drivers were going over the dock plates and the USBs were vibrating out of the back and over time, shattering the USB connection points from frequent vibration when the USB connectors for our keyboards and our scanners were not pushed in all the way.

I have 2.5 meters of PLA per module, so can produce about 90 of these for about 20.00.
Cost of our docking mounts? 500 per and we damage about 4 to 8 of them each month and have to replace them.(we have about 240 forklifts country wide),so yeah you do the math..
Sizewise I think I can print about 20 or 30 of them on the printer.
Current infill is about 10 percent(prototype) Since as all they need to do is hold the USBs in. Will most likely boost to 25 percent for production due to vibration.

I realize this is a unique model however, I am handing over the fusion export as well as the STL so people can make the edits needed to suit their needs.

title: Trophy Wall Mount for Bullet Bill / Banzai Bill
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a trophy holder for the beautiful BULLET BILL / BANZAI BILL designed by Martin Moore @FORGE 3D, which can be found at https://www.myminifactory.com/object/bullet-bill-26743
I thought it would be a fun way to display the Bill as a trophy like a fish or a game animal and designed this tacky looking back plate.
This wall mount features holes in the back so it can be hung on two pins, hooks or nails. I tried to keep the design in a way that it is non interfering to much with the design of the bullet.
The whole thing is fairly robust, I would however not hang my coat on it.
Bill itself has to be downloaded from the link above and printed separately.

Printer:

CR-10

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer hight

Infill:

20%

Notes:
  • This print is designed, that it needs no supports or rafts.
  • The bracket is preferably printed in the same color as Bill's body.
  • If the bracket is printed with three solid bottom and top layers the ring will be solid, which is desirable for rigidity.
  • The back plate can be printed in the color of anyones liking.
    I chose white since it makes the Bill stand out.
  • The parts need to be oriented so, that they will lie flat on the print bed.

1. De-burr the edges of the rectangular tab of the bracket as well as the hole.

Cut some of the tab's and rectangular hole's edges away, so it will be easier to insert it into the back plate. Don't however insert it yet.

2. Place the round part of the bracket over the thread of Bill's body

Make sure that things are in the right orientation:

  • The flat part of the design must be placed towards Bill's body.
  • The rectangular part needs to point backwards while Bill is pointing from left to right.
3. Screw the endcap onto Bill's body

The endcap should be tightened so much, that the ring and some part of the rectangular tab are squeezed in between.

4. Push rectangular tab into back plate

Don't use to much force while pushing the tab into the backplate to prevent the tab from braking of the bracket.

Design your own backplate

You are encouraged to design your own backplate. The rectangular hole should be 6.4 mm x 15.2 mm and 7 mm deep.
Below are the outer dimensions of my design which might serve as a guideline.

title: Dog Collar Parachute Clip Male and Female - with cut out

description.text:
I needed a replacement clip for a dog collar but since the collar material was sewn shut, I couldn't simply remove the broken clip and slide on a new one. Instead I had to break off what remained of the old clip and attach the new one without breaking the seams of the collar. That's where this clip comes in. It features a small gap where the collar portion goes which allows you to pull the collar material through it to attach the new clip without breaking the collar seams.

I have "stress tested" it by taking my dog for a walk and by pulling on it with all of my strength, and it seems extremely sturdy! I wouldn't trust it with a body weight load or anything but it allowed me to keep a collar instead of throwing it away.

Printer:

MonoPrice Mini Select v2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100

Notes:

I used 100% infill as I am using it for my dog's collar and I didn't want pieces to snap. When completed I fed the collar material between the gap and pull it through using a needle nose pliers as it was too small of a space to get my fingers into.

author: themi7ch

description.text: Coin I made in Autodesk Maya. Modeled after the Daggerfall Covenant logo. I am still a beginner so bare with me. Took about 10 hours. Criticism and help is welcome. Hope everyone likes it.
Autodesk maya 2014. The coin is three parts. The lion started an a square, the coin was then made over it as a cylinder and the ear was a cylinder as well.

As seen in Mad Max 3! If you have a spare few minutes and a laser cutter, you too can have a low-resolution model to play with.

Designed for laser cutting in ~3.3mm MDF.

Assembly requires glue, but should be straightforward. The balance is off, so it won't sit on the landing gear. You could potentially hollow the middle nose section and weight it, but I haven't.

~160mm wingspan.

Glue together. It should be a reasonably tight fit, but the wings won't stay without glue.

The lower wing should allow you to align the fuselage sides more accurately.

I got glue everywhere so I have sanded mine back and am in the process of high-fill primer prior to doing a proper paint job.

Traced this from an orthogonal projection in Fusion360, extruded, tested assembly for fit, before exporting to Slicer, and from there to an SVG file.

I had a few revisions, adding thickness to the fuselage and fixing minor issues with windows.

Should be printed using a flexible material (if not, you will not be able to get it over the hinge without disassembling it).

Should also fit Tomtom Runner 3 and Spark 3 (let me know if it fit!)

Try printing with 100% infill.

Infill:

100%

title: Cute Octopus Cyclone Marble Machine Motor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Cute Octopus says "Hey, what are you doing with that electric motor, no, stop!"

I wanted a motor to drive my marble machine, but didn't want to include batteries and also wanted something that was a nice feature.

I used Eddiie's motor adaptor for an N20 and a Cute Octopus, subtracted an N20 shape and some holes from the octopus, and away you go!

These N20 100rpm motors are cheap on ebay - choose your own voltage.

I may do a version two that doesn't need the cap from the marble machine as it's part of the octopus, which means I won't need the pegs. Dunno.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sCVC6EpMVlw&feature=youtu.be

Update: The motor can get quite hot if run for a long time with a heavy load. This causes the PLA to soften and the D shaft to slip. I may fit a drive gear and modify the cap to take this. In the mean time, glue!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.12 or 0.2

Infill:

15% maybe

Notes:

A small brim around the pegs really helps.

Scale them down 1-2% if they are too tight.

Assembly

The holes may need chasing with a drill and then put the pegs in (and test fit on machine) before fitting motor.

Getting the motor shaft into the adaptor may require carefully heating it. Note where the flat is for the motor D shart and maybe mark it with a pen.

Carefully solder wires to the motor. Mine needed the + and - swapping to run the right way.

The wires connected to the motor will need wiggling through the hole in the octopus, which takes a minute or so. The motor is then a push fit.

Have fun!

author: wigarga

title: OpenLOCK Cut-Stone Walls with side clips

description.text:
OpenLOCK 6.0 support for Cut-Stone, along with openlock triplex and long requested walls with magnetic bases!
There's a lot going on here, so read the instructions below.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

General
  • All files in this release are on an Inch basis. They will mostly line up with 25mm based tiles (like all my non OpenLOCK stuff, and Dwarven Forge)
  • Because of the openlock ports, resizing them will not work. If you want 25mm based versions, contact me and I'll see about doing those versions.
A and BA walls
  • A.wall and A.wall.half files are full walls, no gluing necessary. These are openlock triplex
  • The rest of the walls need to be assembled, you will need to print a base and a top
  • There are two types of top. Normal and narrow (indicated by .narrow in the file name). The normal files are like all previous cut-stone releases. Narrow are thinner, and are what are pictured above. I designed these mostly because I think they make rooms a little more visually interesting when using full thickness columns.
  • The base options are magnetic + openlock and openlock triplex
E and A floors
  • Work like normal. Use a base and a floor that you glue on top of it.
  • The height of the floor is designed to match up with my normal OpenForge tiles. If you want them to match with most openlock tiles, print them at 50% height on the z axis. To do this is Slic3r, you can right click on the object and select "Scale z"
Columns
  • The full height columns are fairly straight forward.
  • I personally choose to glue the openlock clips into columns, just because it makes them a little more convenient.
  • For the half height columns, there's a problem that clips bump into each other on I and L columns. I added a clip that is missing one arm that makes it so you can fit them in the half height columns. I strongly suggest gluing the clips into the columns in this case, as it will not be particularly strong.

comments.text: Any chance we could get X and T columns  to go with this set , preferable with 2 clip holes on every face? Otherwise spectacular job as always, printing your models is half the reason I have a printer.
comments.author: TiddlyWink

comments.text: When I saw these I made an assumption and immediately looked for the top prongs for openlock wall stacking, isn't that the main reason to have side clips for stability as you go up? or is there another benefit to using side clips for single height layouts that I'm missing? Thanks for any guidance!

description.text:
This is a revolver discs that can also be used as a snap cap for the Chiappa Rhino revolvers chambered in .357 Magnum.
This may fit the Rhinos that are chambered in other calibers, unfortunately I only have access to one chambered in .357 Magnum. Print out of ABS with 100% infill.
The disc is rather thin so do not expect it to last forever when using it as a snap cap.

comments.text: dude! i have been seriously considering getting one of these bad boys (the chiappa rhino) the fact that its mostly aluminum throws me off. like my old school stainless frames. how well do they operate? i hear they have more moving parts than a conventional revolver. and normally less is more. is that the case this time around? i guess i just want a good review...
comments.author: onus

comments.text:
I tried to post a replay here, it must have been too long, so I sent you a message. Hopefully it made it through.
In short if you can get around the concept/idea that the Rhino is something new and find the aesthetics of it to be at least some what appealing, you would enjoy it if you bought one.
They are well built and very reliable. They are built well to do everything Chiappa says they are for, a low recoil ergonomic 357mag revolver design for: self-defense, competition shooting, and hunting.
The common missfire (skipping over a chamber) happens when you short-stroke the trigger.
comments.author: onus

comments.text: the Chiapas "Rhino".  What a beautiful gun.  What metal is it made of, so it could actually fire?   If 3-D'd with lasers and titanium powders, it could be real, light and effective in affording protection.  Wasn't the red hexagonal disc, a type of "speed-loader", allowing a quick re-load of all 6 chambers, almost like the clip of an auto-pistol?   The current advantage of a revolver like the "Rhino", is that the brass cartridges can be retained, once fired, to be hand-re-loaded later.  Is the red-hexagon thin enough so that the hammer can ignite the cartridge, and is there a possibility of melted-plastic clogging the mechanism, so the chambers can't advance to be ignited/fired?   In other words, the cartridge-primer-cap should be exposed to allow the weapon to easily fire and protect.   With no holes for the firing-pin to access the primer-cap, the cartridge might not fire, giving the owner an expensive "club" to have brought to a possible gun-fight.
comments.author: mercendarian

comments.text:
The frame is some sort of Aluminum alloy (eargle perhaps?), while the cylinder and barrel are steel.
Even the 60DS (shown in the picture) which has a 6” barrel is rather light, it almost feels like a toy not a real revolver coming in at 2lbs.The actual flag-ship model is the 20DS has 2” barrel is about 1.5lbs, which is designed to be a concealed carry gun.
The red revolver disc it comes with is about half the thickness as what I made and it is also a circular shape, not hexagonal to contour of the cylinder. As is, it is designed to not allow you to place any cartridges into the revolver for safety. The revolver disc I made is 1.45mm thick and to fit in the groove of the cases it needs to be about 0.75mm thick. They do make moon clips for speed loading, in fact they come with a couple moon-clips from the factory (and leave everyone asking where can buy more moon clips LOL). The disc I made here is more for storage/display or training and tournaments so you can tell at a glace that it is unloaded. It also can be used as a cheap snap cap if you want to get use to the action.
comments.author: mercendarian

author: Superclodbuster

title: Model railroad, Trestle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a model of a wood trestle for model railroads. This design is based on pictures on the internet and does not model a specific trestle.  
A trestle is a challenge to print, although I've had good luck. I took some liberties in the design to make printing easier.  
Three versions are provided: one for O or S, one for HO, and one for N or Z. Each trestle is designed so that a train can run underneath it. Scale the models to meet your needs.  
See Instructions for more information on printing and scaling. The pictures do not show the final .stl files provided.

This is a model of a wood trestle for model railroads. Three versions are provided: one for O or S, one for HO, and one for N or Z. Eachtrestle is designed so that a train can run underneath it. Scale the models to meet your needs. The dimensions of the O design are
  • overall height, 120.5 mm
  • clearance under trestle 110 mm
  • track width 58.5 mm
  • width at bottom 121.5 mm
  • length 200 mm
    • The dimensions of the HO design are
  • overall height, 84 mm
  • clearance under trestle 75 mm
  • track width 36.8 mm
  • width at bottom 73.8 mm
  • length 200 mm
    • The dimensions of the N design (also for Z) are
  • overall height, 47 mm
  • clearance under trestle 42.5 mm
  • track width 18.4 mm
  • width at bottom 39.6 mm
  • length 125 mm
    • Parts list: None. Assembly instructions: None. Print upside down. The trestle tends to warp lengthwise. Adhesion to the build plate is very important. The final designs were not printed. They were made for Thingiverse. I printed earlier and similar designs for O, HO and N (see the pictures). The trestles were printed on a Makerbor Replicator2
  • I recommend that you print them upside down, but the HO and N models will print rightside up with OK results.
  • PLA (Makerbot filament)
  • Printed: Low(faster) resolution, 8% infill, 2 shells, 0.30 mm layer height, 230C
  • a raft was not used
  • the trestles warped a little lengthwise. i carefully used a heat gun to warm the plastic enough to bend them straight.
    • There may be some cleanup needed in the bents (ie. supports). Some best practices for printing:
  • optimize print parameters for your printer, filament, etc (only you can determine the best parameters)
  • use good filament
  • level your build plate prior to printing complex parts. it's worth the few minutes it takes. always level after removing tape, or if pulling hard to remove a part.
  • make sure the build plate is clean.
  • if using blue tape, stretch it tight when applying it to the build plate.
  • if you have small holes in the blue tape, the bridge should still print without any problems.
  • pre-feed the filament 30 to 60-s before printing (i.e., run load for 30-60s)
  • do not print several complicated parts in one build (do complex parts by themselves)
  • I find that printing faster is better (probably so the filament can't ball up in one spot)
  • when the filament spool gets low, the filament can be tightly wound on the spool and the filament may not feed properly... take special care...
  • when a new spool is used, it is easy for the filament to jump outside the spool and then it will bind up later around the spool holder ruining your build
  • make sure it is easy for the filament to enter the filament feed tube. others have designed spools, mounts, etc. for that purpose. i use a small rope that forces the filament away from the spool before entering the filament feed tube.
  • if you hear clicking when printing, that may be a result of the filament wrapped around the spool and not feeding
  • make sure that there aren't any obstructions on the spool, such as some filament used to hold it in place during shipping
  • for the replicaor2, look at the blob a filament in the left front part of the build plate and then the trail of filament to the biuild location. there should be a glob, and the line of filament should be continuous and smooth
  • one way to remove parts when using blue tape is to use a very thin spatula bought in craft-art stores (advice from youtube). get one with a wide, blunt front end (not long and thin). mine is 11 mils thick (0.011") and 20-mm wide at the front. a painting spatula/scraper in hardware stores won't work and may damage the build plate. (I use blue tape so I don't have any best practices for bare plates, heated plates or for other tapes like mylar)
  • perform regular maintenance (grease, etc).
  • when I continued to have problems printing even after performing maintenance, following troublshooting instructions, changing filaments, cleaning gears, cleaning everything, optimizing print parameters, changing temperatures, etc., I bought a new extruder assembly from Makerbot and it solved all of my problems.

I have not listed G scale because it's too big for my designed parts. Disclaimer: This trestle was not based on a specific prototype and there isn't a true scale for this item. The design is based loosely on Google images of various trestles around the world. Features and dimensions of real trestles were altered for the simplicity of the design and to make the trestle printable.

title: Robo 3D R1 Plus Shroud with Cable Hook

description.text: This was a simple combination to allow an easier alternative to a cable chain. It seems to work fine if you add the two screws to fasten it down.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

comments.text: Does this not affect the X homing / min end stop? It looks like the shroud goes noticeably further than the screw for the endstop.
comments.author: nathanbuck88

comments.text: No. It’s barely sticks out any more than the motor itself and it doesn’t take up any more space than any other shroud does.
comments.author: nathanbuck88

comments.text: I have a robo 3d r1 plus, and I like the idea, but could you describe it and how to use it in more detail?
comments.author: pndb

comments.text: It fits just like the shroud and has holes on both sides to be screwed into the back and front of the stepper motor. Just simply hook your cables into the hook and mount it to the stepper motor.
comments.author: pndb
